\sigma\left(\varphi_{E}\left(e_{1, i}\right) g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{j, 1}\right)\right) \cdot e_{1,1} & =\pi\left(\varphi_{E}\left(e_{1, i}\right) g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{j, 1}\right)\right) \\
& =\pi\left(\varphi_{E}\left(e_{1, i}\right)\right) \pi\left(g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g\right) \pi\left(\varphi_{E}\left(e_{j, 1}\right)\right) \\
& =\lambda^{2} \cdot e_{1, i} \cdot \pi\left(g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g\right) \cdot e_{j, 1}
\end{aligned}
$$

and thus

$$
\sigma\left(\varphi_{E}\left(e_{1, i}\right) g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{j, 1}\right)\right) \cdot e_{i, j}=\lambda^{2} \cdot \pi\left(g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g\right)
$$

which in conjunction with (4.7) shows that $\varrho\left(g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g\right)=\pi\left(g \varphi_{E}\left(e_{i, j}\right) g\right)$ as we wanted. It follows now that $\varrho\left(h_{E}\right)=\pi\left(h_{E}\right)$. Since $\pi$ was picked so that $\left\|h_{E}\right\|=\left\|\pi\left(h_{E}\right)\right\|$, we have that $\left\|h_{E}\right\|=\left\|\varrho\left(h_{E}\right)\right\|$. Let $h_{E}^{\prime}:=$ $f^{\prime} a^{1 / 2} \varphi_{E}^{\left(j_{0}\right)} \psi_{E}^{\left(j_{0}\right)}\left(1_{A}\right) a^{1 / 2} f^{\prime}$. Since $\left\|h_{E}-h_{E}^{\prime}\right\|<\frac{\eta}{2(d+1)}$ by (vi) of Proposition 4.1 and since $\varrho$ is contractive, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|h_{E}\right\| & =\left\|\varrho\left(h_{E}\right)\right\| \\
& =\left\|\varrho\left(h_{E}-h_{E}^{\prime}\right)+\varrho\left(h_{E}^{\prime}\right)\right\| \\
& \leq \frac{\eta}{2(d+1)}+\left\|\varrho\left(h_{E}^{\prime}\right)\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

Using in the first line of the chain of inequalities below that $\varrho$ is positive and $0 \leq h_{E}^{\prime} \leq f^{\prime} a f^{\prime}$ (as $\varphi \psi$ is contractive), we also have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\varrho\left(h_{E}^{\prime}\right)\right\| & \leq\left\|\varrho\left(f^{\prime} a f^{\prime}\right)\right\|_{M_{r}} \\
& \leq r \cdot \max _{1 \leq i \leq r}\left|\varrho\left(f^{\prime} a f^{\prime}\right)_{i, i}\right| \\
& \stackrel{(4.6)}{\leq r} \cdot\left\|\Phi\left(f^{\prime} a f^{\prime}\right)\right\| \\
& =r \cdot\left\|f^{\prime} \Phi(a) f^{\prime}\right\| \\
& <r \cdot \frac{\eta}{2(d+1) r_{\max }} \\
& \leq \frac{\eta}{2(d+1)}
\end{aligned}
$$

and combining this estimate with (4.8) yields that $\left\|h_{E}\right\|<\eta /(d+1)$. Since $E$ was an arbitrary matrix summand of $F^{\left(j_{0}\right)}$, (4.2) implies that $\left\|f^{\prime} \varphi^{\left(j_{0}\right)} \psi^{\left(j_{0}\right)}(a) f^{\prime}\right\|<\eta /(d+1)$, and since this holds for any $j_{0} \in\{0, \ldots, d\}$, the proof is complete.

Remark 4.4. It is plausible that the conditional expectation of a diagonal pair $(D \subset A)$ is automatically hereditary when $A$ is assumed to be nuclear. On the other hand, hereditariness cannot be expected to hold automatically without any amenability assumptions: by [27, Corollary 5.1], any non-exact discrete group $G$ admits a free action on a space $X$ such that the induced

action $G \curvearrowright C(X)$ fails to be exact in the sense of [29, Definition 1.2]. By [29, Proposition 1.3], there exists some positive element in the crossed product $C(X) \rtimes_{t} G$ that does not belong to the ideal generated by its conditional expectation, and in particular the conditional expectation fails to be hereditary. Regularity of $(D \subset A)$ cannot be relaxed either, as the following example illustrates.

Example 4.5. We give an example of a unital $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-pair $(D \subset A)$ where $A$ is separable and $\mathrm{AF}, D$ has zero-dimensional spectrum and is a masa in $A,(D \subset A)$ has the unique extension property, the induced conditional expectation $\Phi: A \rightarrow D$ is faithful and there exists a projection $p \in A$ so that $p \notin \operatorname{her}(\Phi(p))$. The pair $(D \subset A)$ described below is not regular.

Consider the $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-diagonal $\left(D_{2^{\infty}} \subset M_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ where $M_{2^{\infty}}$ is the UHF $\mathrm{C}^{*}$ algebra of type $2^{\infty}$ and $D_{2^{\infty}}$ is its standard diagonal. Consider also the canonical (unitally contained) sub- $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Let $E: M_{2^{\infty}} \rightarrow D_{2^{\infty}}$ denote the associated faithful conditional expectation and observe that $\left.E\right|_{M_{2}^{\otimes k}}$ coincides with $E_{2}^{\otimes k}: M_{2}^{\otimes k} \rightarrow D_{2}^{\otimes k}$.

Consider now the $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $B:=\ell^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{N}, M_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ of bounded sequences over $M_{2^{\infty}}$ and let $D \subset B$ denote the (abelian) sub- $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra of convergent sequences over $D_{2^{\infty}}$, namely $D:=C\left(\mathbb{N}^{(+)}, D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$, where $\mathbb{N}^{(+)}=\mathbb{N} \sqcup\{\infty\}$ is the one point compactification of $\mathbb{N}$. We define the projection $p=\left(p_{n}\right)_{n \geq 1} \in$ $B$, where $p_{n} \in M_{2}^{\otimes n} \subset M_{2^{\infty}}$ is the projection given by

$$
p_{n}:=\frac{1}{2^{n}} \sum_{\bar{\imath}, \bar{\jmath} \in\{1,2\}^{n}} e_{i_{1}, j_{1}} \otimes \cdots \otimes e_{i_{n}, j_{n}}
$$

where $\bar{\imath}=\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n}\right)$ and $\bar{\jmath}=\left(j_{1}, \ldots, j_{n}\right)$. Let $\mathrm{C}^{*}(D, p)=: A \subset B$. Note that $(D \subset A)$ is a unital $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-pair where $A$ is separable and $D$ has zerodimensional spectrum.

We first show that $(D \subset A)$ has the unique extension property. Viewing $D$ as the tensor product of the $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $C\left(\mathbb{N}^{(+)}\right)$of convergent sequences (over $\mathbb{C}$ ) with $D_{2^{\infty}}$, we have that the set $\operatorname{PS}(D)$ of pure states on $D$ is described as

$$
\left\{\mathrm{ev}_{n} \otimes \psi: n \in \mathbb{N}, \psi \in \operatorname{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)\right\} \sqcup\left\{\mathrm{ev}_{\infty} \otimes \psi: \psi \in \operatorname{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)\right\}
$$

where $\mathrm{ev}_{n}\left(\lambda_{j}\right)_{j \geq 1}:=\lambda_{n}$ for $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\mathrm{ev}_{\infty}\left(\lambda_{j}\right)_{j \geq 1}:=\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \lambda_{j}$ for all $\left(\lambda_{j}\right)_{j \geq 1} \in C\left(\mathbb{N}^{(+)}\right)$.

Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\psi \in \operatorname{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ and let $\varrho \in \mathrm{S}(B)$ be a state extending $\mathrm{ev}_{n} \otimes \psi$. If $\iota_{n}: M_{2^{\infty}} \hookrightarrow B$ denotes the $n$-th coordinate embedding, then $\varrho \circ \iota_{n}$ is a state on $M_{2^{\infty}}$ extending $\psi$, whence by the unique extension property of $\left(D_{2^{\infty}} \subset M_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ we have $\varrho \circ \iota_{n}=\psi \circ E$. Also, it follows directly by its definition that $\varrho$ vanishes on sequences in $B$ where the $n$-th entry is zero. This shows that $\varrho$ is unique, so $\mathrm{ev}_{n} \otimes \psi$ extends uniquely to $B$ (and thus also to $A$ ).

Now let $\psi \in \mathrm{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ and consider the pure state $\theta:=\mathrm{ev}_{\infty} \otimes \psi \in \mathrm{PS}(D)$. Clearly $\theta$ will fail to extend uniquely on $B$, since if $\omega \in \beta \mathbb{N} \backslash \mathbb{N}$ is any free ultrafilter, the state $\left(b_{j}\right)_{j \geq 1} \mapsto \lim _{j \rightarrow \omega} \psi\left(E\left(b_{j}\right)\right)$ will extend $\theta$ on $B$. Nevertheless, since $A=\mathrm{C}^{*}(D, p)$, if we show that any extension $\bar{\theta}$ of $\theta$ on $A$ vanishes at $p$, then since $p$ is a projection we will have that $0=|\bar{\theta}(p)|^{2}=$ $\bar{\theta}\left(p^{2}\right)$, and so $p$ will lie in the multiplicative domain of $\bar{\theta}$. As $D$ also lies in the multiplicative domain of $\bar{\theta}$ since $\theta \in \operatorname{PS}(D)$, we have that $\bar{\theta}$ vanishes on any product of elements from $D \cup\{p\}$ whenever at least one term $p$ appears. Since $A=\mathrm{C}^{*}(D, p)$, this shows that the extension of $\theta$ is uniquely determined on $A$. Now since $\psi \in \mathrm{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ and the spectrum of $D_{2^{\infty}}$ is the Cantor space $\{1,2\}^{\mathbb{N}}$, there is a point $x=\left(x_{j}\right)_{j \geq 1} \in\{1,2\}^{\mathbb{N}}$ such that $\psi$ corresponds to evaluation at $x$. For $k \in \mathbb{N}$ set $\bar{x}_{k}:=\left(x_{j}\right)_{j=1}^{k} \in\{1,2\}^{k}$ and, for a $k$-tuple $\bar{y}:=\left(y_{j}\right)_{j=1}^{k} \in\{1,2\}^{k}$ set $e_{\bar{y}}:=e_{y_{1}, y_{1}} \otimes \cdots \otimes e_{y_{k}, y_{k}} \in D_{2}^{\otimes k} \subset D_{2^{\infty}}$. Now let $e_{k}:=\left(0, \ldots, 0, e_{\bar{x}_{k}}, e_{\bar{x}_{k}}, \ldots\right) \in D$, where the segment of zeroes in the beginning of $e_{k}$ has length $k$. Clearly $\theta\left(e_{k}\right)=1$ for all $k \in \mathbb{N}$, so each $e_{k}$ lies in the multiplicative domain of $\theta$, hence $\theta(p)=\theta\left(e_{k} p e_{k}\right)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{N}$. We have that $\left\|e_{k} p e_{k}\right\|=\sup _{n \geq k+1}\left\|e_{\bar{x}_{k}} p_{n} e_{\bar{x}_{k}}\right\|_{M_{2}^{\otimes n}}$, and for $n \geq k+1$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|e_{\bar{x}_{k}} p_{n} e_{\bar{x}_{k}}\right\|_{M_{2}^{\otimes n}} & =\left\|\frac{1}{2^{n}} \sum e_{x_{1}, x_{1}} \otimes \cdots \otimes e_{x_{k}, x_{k}} \otimes e_{i_{k+1}, j_{k+1}} \otimes \cdots \otimes e_{i_{n}, j_{n}}\right\| \\
& =\frac{1}{2^{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the sum is taken over all $i_{k+1}, j_{k+1}, \ldots, i_{n}, j_{n} \in\{1,2\}$. We thus conclude that $\left\|e_{k} p e_{k}\right\|=2^{-k} \rightarrow 0$, so $\theta(p)=\lim _{k} \theta\left(e_{k} p e_{k}\right)=0$, as we wanted.

Since $(D \subset A)$ has the unique extension property, $D$ is a masa in $A$ and there exists a unique conditional expectation $\Phi: A \rightarrow D$, that also has the property that the unique extension of a pure state $\theta \in \operatorname{PS}(D)$ is given by $\theta \circ \Phi$ [2, Remark 2.6, Corollary 2.7]. Evidently $\Phi$ is faithful: if $a=\left(a_{j}\right)_{j \geq 1} \in A_{+} \subset \ell^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{N}, M_{2^{\infty}}\right)_{+}$is such that $\Phi(a)=0$, then for $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\psi \in \operatorname{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$, we have $\psi\left(E\left(a_{n}\right)\right)=\left(\operatorname{ev}_{n} \otimes \psi\right) \circ \Phi(a)=0$ and since $\psi$ is arbitrary this shows that $E\left(a_{n}\right)=0$ in $D_{2^{\infty}}$, hence $a_{n}=0$ in $M_{2^{\infty}}$ since $E$ is faithful, and since $n \in \mathbb{N}$ was arbitrary, we conclude that $a=0$. Note however that $\Phi$ is not hereditary: since $\Phi(p)$ is a convergent sequence in $D_{2^{\infty}}$, let $d \in D_{2^{\infty}}$ denote its limit. As explained earlier, for any $\psi \in \operatorname{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ we have that $\left(\mathrm{ev}_{\infty} \otimes \psi\right) \circ \Phi(p)=0$, so $\psi(d)=0$ for all $\psi \in \operatorname{PS}\left(D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$, hence $d=0$, which shows that $\Phi(p) \in C_{0}\left(\mathbb{N}, D_{2^{\infty}}\right)$ and thus $\operatorname{her}(\Phi(p)) \subset C_{0}\left(\mathbb{N}, M_{2^{\infty}}\right)$. Clearly $p \notin C_{0}\left(\mathbb{N}, M_{2^{\infty}}\right)$, so $p \notin \operatorname{her}(\Phi(p))$.

Note that $(D \subset A)$ is non-regular, since $\mathcal{N}_{A}(D)=D$. Also, $A$ is an AF algebra, which we prove by showing that $A$ is locally AF. Since $A$ is generated by $D \cup\{p\}$, it suffices to show that if $\Omega$ is a finite subset of $D \cup\{p\}$ and $\varepsilon>0$, then there exists a finite-dimensional sub- $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $F \subset A$ such that $\operatorname{dist}(a, F)<\varepsilon$ for all $a \in \Omega$.

Since each $d \in \Omega \cap D$ is a convergent sequence with entries in $D_{2^{\infty}}$ we obtain $k \in \mathbb{N}$ such that each $d \in D$ is approximated by a sum of a sequence with the first $k$ entries lying in $D_{2}^{\otimes k}$ and the rest of the entries being 0 , and a sequence with the first $k$ entries being 0 and the rest of the entries being

all the same and equal to some element in $D_{2}^{\otimes k}$. Set

$$
C_{k}:=\left\{\left(b_{j}\right)_{j \geq 1} \in B: b_{1}, \ldots, b_{k} \in M_{2}^{\otimes k}, b_{j}=0 \text { for } j \geq k+1\right\} \cong \bigodot_{j=1}^{k} M_{2}^{\otimes k}
$$

and $h_{k}:=1_{B}-1_{C_{k}} \in D$ and for $\bar{x} \in\{1,2\}^{k}$ set $\tilde{e}_{\bar{x}}:=(0, \ldots, 0, e_{\bar{x}}, e_{\bar{x}}, \ldots) \in$ $D$ where the initial segment of zeroes here has length $k$. We claim that there exists a finite-dimensional $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $F_{k} \subset A$ with $1_{F_{k}}=h_{k}$ and such that, if $q_{k}:=h_{k} p=\left(0, \ldots, 0, p_{k+1}, p_{k+2}, \ldots\right) \in A$, then

$$
\left\{\tilde{e}_{\bar{x}}: \bar{x} \in\{1,2\}^{k}\right\} \cup\left\{q_{k}\right\} \subset F_{k}
$$

In particular $F_{k}$ will contain every sequence of the form $(0, \ldots, 0, d, d, d, \ldots)$ where $d \in D_{2}^{\otimes k}$, and so $F:=\left(C_{k} \cap A\right)+F_{k}$ will be a finite-dimensional sub- $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra of $A$ that approximately contains $\Omega$, as explained above.

To prove the claim, for $\bar{x}, \bar{y} \in\{1,2\}^{k}$ we set $h_{\bar{x}, \bar{y}}:=2^{k} \tilde{e}_{\bar{x}} \cdot p \cdot \tilde{e}_{\bar{y}}$ and straightforward calculations show that $\left\{h_{\bar{x}, \bar{y}}\right\}_{\bar{x}, \bar{y} \in\{1,2\}^{k}}$ form a system of matrix units for $M_{2^{k}}$. We can thus define a (non-unital) embedding $\iota: M_{2^{k}} \hookrightarrow A$ by declaring $\iota\left(e_{\bar{x}, \bar{y}}\right):=h_{\bar{x}, \bar{y}}$ on the matrix units $\left\{e_{\bar{x}, \bar{y}}\right\}_{\bar{x}, \bar{y} \in\{1,2\}^{k}}$ of $M_{2^{k}}$ and extending linearly. It is clear that $\iota(1) \leq h_{k}$, that $q_{k}=\iota\left(\frac{1}{2^{k}} \sum_{\bar{x}, \bar{y}} e_{\bar{x}, \bar{y}}\right)$ and that $\tilde{e}_{\bar{x}} \cdot \iota(1)=h_{\bar{x}, \bar{x}}=\iota(1) \cdot \tilde{e}_{\bar{x}}$. Set $g_{\bar{x}}:=\left(h_{k}-\iota(1)\right) \tilde{e}_{\bar{x}}=\tilde{e}_{\bar{x}}-h_{\bar{x}, \bar{x}}$ for all $\bar{x} \in\{1,2\}^{k}$. We have that $\left\{g_{\bar{x}}\right\}_{\bar{x} \in\{1,2\}^{k}}$ are pairwise orthogonal projections that are all orthogonal to $\iota\left(M_{2^{k}}\right)$, hence $F_{k}:=\operatorname{span}\left\{g_{\bar{x}}: \bar{x} \in\{1,2\}^{k}\right\}+\iota\left(M_{2^{k}}\right) \subset A$ is a sub- $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra isomorphic to $\mathbb{C}^{2^{k}} \oplus M_{2^{k}}$. As we already noted, $q_{k} \in$ $\iota\left(M_{2^{k}}\right) \subset F_{k}$ and also, $\tilde{e}_{\bar{x}}=g_{\bar{x}}+h_{\bar{x}, \bar{x}} \in F_{k}$ for all $\bar{x} \in\{1,2\}^{k}$, as we wanted.

abstract:
We introduce diagonal comparison, a regularity property of diagonal pairs
where the sub-C*-algebra has totally disconnected spectrum, and establish its
equivalence with the concurrence of strict comparison of the ambient C*-algebra
and dynamical comparison of the underlying dynamics induced by the partial
action of the normalisers. As an application, we show that for diagonal pairs
arising from principal minimal transformation groupoids with totally
disconnected unit space, diagonal comparison is equivalent to tracial
Z-stability of the pair and that it is implied by finite diagonal dimension.
  In-between, we show that any projection of the diagonal sub-C*-algebra can be
uniformly tracially divided, and explore a property of conditional expectations
onto abelian sub-C*-algebras, namely containment of every positive element in
the hereditary subalgebra generated by its conditional expectation. We show
that the expectation associated to a C*-pair with finite diagonal dimension is
always hereditary in that sense, and we give an example where this property
does not occur.
